claim.hypothesis: Realistic threat is positively associated with negative affect experienced over the course of the subsequent week.
claim.hypothesis_location: the abstract, p. 5 (Unique and Sometimes Opposite Consequences of Realistic Versus Symbolic Threats section)
claim.statement: the authors examined the association between realistic threat (at T1), and all criterion outcomes assessed one week later (at T2), simultaneously in one model.This analysis yielded that realistic threat (at T1) was positively associated with negative affect experienced over the course of a subsequent week. b=4.02,p=0.000.
claim.statement_location: criterion validity section on p. 25 and Table 10 (Negative affect row and Realistic Threat (Time 1) column)

data.source: survey constructed by the authors (a brief and psychometrically sound 10-item scale measuring realistic or symbolic threat)
data.access_details: The authors made the data available on the OSF (they ask to email Frank Kachanoff at fkach@email.unc.edu for the access code; the OSF address is not stated in the paper  so it's probably best to email them about it too; there's a link to https://aspredicted.org/blind.php?x=2ed62c but it is not explained what exact information we can find there)

method.description: The researchers developed and validated a 10-item Integrated COVID-19 Threat Scale measuring realistic threat (health/economic danger) and symbolic threat (threats to sociocultural identity). They checked the psychometric properties of the scale and tested how each threat predicted wellbeing and adherence to public-health behaviors.
method.steps: 1.The authors recruited U.S. participants via MTurk and administered baseline survey at time T1. 2.They they administered the 10-item Integrated COVID-19 Threat Scale to measure realistic and symbolic threat. 3. Next, they assessed the factor structure and longitudinal invariance of the threat scale (Study 3). 4. They contacted participants one week later (time T2) and administered psychological distress (Beck anxiety scale, COVID-19 impact intrusion and COVID-19 impact avoidance scales), psychological well-being (general satisfaction with life using Dienerâ€™s five-item scale, PANAS short form), and attitudinal and behavioral responses to COVID-19 (compliance with the Center for Infectious Diseases guidelines, support for restrictive policies to prevent COVID-19, and social identity affirming behaviors in isolation). 5. Next, they scored scales according to instrument instructions (means for most measures; summed scores for Beck Anxiety Inventory, PANAS, and COVID-19 impact scales). 6. Finally, the authors estimated structural equation model (SEM) predicting all T2 outcomes simultaneously from T1 realistic and symbolic threat variables and allowing predictors and outcomes to covary within the SEM framework to capture interrelations among outcomes.
method.tools_software: SemTools R package was used for invariance testing

results.summary: Realistic threat (at T1) was positively associated with negative affect experienced over the course of a subsequent week.

numerical_results.unit: non standardized path coefficient from SEM model

metadata.original_paper_title: Measuring Two Distinct Psychological Threats of COVID-19 and their Unique Impacts on Wellbeing and Adherence to Public Health Behaviors.
